title: What to Put in Your Spring Forage Mix

tasks.task: Discussing and planning spring cover crop mixes for forage options
subtasks: Navigating the smart mix calculator on the GreenCoverSeed website
Entering a zip code for zip code-specific recommendations (hometown of the user)
Choosing a bagging option (tote bag for this example)
Deciding on non-organic certification for the mix
Selecting a seeding method (drilled cover in this case)
Considering the timing of the next cash crop (assuming wheat planting after the forage mix)
Setting a goal for the cover crop (supplemental grazing)
Adjusting legume, grass, brassica, and broadleaf species percentages via the smart mix auto adjust button
Choosing specific species (spring forage peas, crimson clover, spring oats, annual rye, kale, collards, and flax)
Determining the final seed composition (e.g., 2 lbs clover, 8 lbs forage peas, 2 lbs rye, 35 lbs oats, 1.5 lbs brassicas, 3 lbs flax)
Verifying the total seed count (approximately 1.5 million seeds per acre)

tasks.task: Navigating potential variations and considerations in seed selection
subtasks: Adjusting seeding rates based on soil fertility and moisture conditions
Considering alternative cereal grains (spring barley, triticale) for specific needs
Evaluating the potential for hay production and current market demand (e.g., low hay inventories due to previous drought)
Assessing the balance between tonnage and cost in seed composition choices
